title: Political backlash over Israeli fan ban at Villa Park . Plus : Are tactics making EPL dull ?
body_text:
The Athletic FC ‚öΩ is The Athletic‚Äôs daily football (or soccer, if you prefer) newsletter. Sign up to receive it directly to your inbox.
Today, we bring you the news that fans of an Israeli team have been banned from an English football ground. It‚Äôs causing controversy and a political backlash. We‚Äôre here to explain.

Plus: Is the Premier League getting boring? And look inside the mind of the midfielder who hit the high notes for Pep Guardiola and Jurgen Klopp.
‚ÄòNational disgrace‚Äô: Starmer and Badenoch slam Villa ban on Maccabi Tel Aviv fans
Matchday four in the Europa League takes place next month and on November 6, Aston Villa host Maccabi Tel Aviv. It‚Äôs not a fixture that, in plain footballing terms, was likely to make major headlines. The competition is in its early stages and is very much the Champions League‚Äôs lesser cousin.
But the game shot to the top of the agenda yesterday after The Athletic revealed that fans of Maccabi Tel Aviv, one of Israel‚Äôs most recognisable clubs, would be banned from attending Villa Park. The decision was made on the advice of West Midlands Police, the constabulary with responsibility for overseeing security at the match. A statement from Villa said it had been implemented on the grounds of ‚Äúpublic safety concerns‚Äù.
Police anticipate that the tie could attract protests over the conflict involving Israel and Hamas in the Middle East, a crisis that, after two years of fighting, is now subject to a negotiated ceasefire. Football has not been immune to the war. Before the ceasefire, there were calls for Israel to be banned from UEFA and FIFA competitions in response to the nation‚Äôs actions in Gaza. Israel‚Äôs recent World Cup qualifier in Norway became highly political, owing in part to Norway‚Äôs pro-Palestinian stance.
Last November, Maccabi Tel Aviv played a Europa League game against Ajax in Amsterdam. The contest was marred by violent disorder, with five people taken to hospital and 62 injured. Maccabi fans were among the victims of the violence. Police reported how others had burned a Palestinian flag and attacked a taxi. An extra 800 officers were on duty because of safety concerns.
Advertisement
Banning away fans from Villa next month, however, is a controversial step, essentially blocking Israeli ‚Äî and therefore many Jewish ‚Äî fans from freely following Maccabi Tel Aviv. Last night, the UK prime minister, Sir Keir Starmer, intervened by publicly criticising the move on X. His post followed another from the leader of the opposition, Kemi Badenoch, who described the ban as a ‚Äúnational disgrace‚Äù.
‚ÄòDecision based on current intelligence‚Äô
Stamer‚Äôs rebuke will intensify the debate around West Midlands Police‚Äôs position in the days ahead. Here‚Äôs what he said in his tweet: ‚ÄúThis is the wrong decision. We will not tolerate antisemitism on our streets. The role of the police is to ensure all football fans can enjoy the game, without fear of violence or intimidation.‚Äù
West Midlands Police had earlier sought to justify its stance ‚Äî which Europa League organisers, UEFA, are expected to follow ‚Äî referencing the trouble seen at the Ajax-Maccabi Tel Aviv meeting 11 months earlier. ‚ÄúThis decision is based on current intelligence and previous incidents, including violent clashes and hate crime offences that occurred during the 2024 UEFA Europa League match between Ajax and Maccabi Tel Aviv in Amsterdam.‚Äù
The clash of views and the depth of the politics involved was further underlined by Ayoub Khan, a member of parliament for the Birmingham Perry Barr constituency, signing a petition calling for the game to be called off, staged in a neutral country or held without an away crowd. The petition said this was to ensure ‚Äúcommunity harmony‚Äù. According to a 2021 census, Birmingham has a 30 per cent Muslim population.
Maccabi Tel Aviv have said nothing about the ban. The Athletic asked the club for comment and is awaiting a response. But the backlash to it, and the delicacy of the entire debate surrounding Gaza, meant it was no surprise to hear this morning that the police and crime commissioner for West Midlands has ordered an immediate review.

News round-up
- Lamine Yamal and Jude Bellingham have jumped into Forbes‚Äô list of the top 10 highest-paid footballers in the world. Cristiano Ronaldo remains way, way out in front on ¬£208million ($280m).

- Juventus are facing a UEFA investigation over a possible breach of the European governing body‚Äôs financial rules. The probe covers the campaigns from 2022-23 to 2024-25.
- A couple of significant injury blows as international football gives way to club football again: Chelsea‚Äôs Cole Palmer is out for another six weeks with a groin problem. And Mikel Arteta confirmed Arsenal have lost Martin Odegaard to ligament damage.
Beautiful game?
I know a hot potato when I see one. Any time spent writing about football, or sports in general, teaches you that certain subjects invite a hail of arrows from the audience. For example, articles daring to besmirch the brilliance of Neymar.
Tactics fall into that category, largely because beauty is in the eye of the beholder (and beholders in football are extraordinarily tribal). When Oli Kay took on that topic yesterday ‚Äî effectively asking if the Premier League was becoming harder to enjoy ‚Äî comments beneath his column landed in spades.
Oli‚Äôs point of view (and he‚Äôs not alone) is that football in England‚Äôs top flight is experiencing an identity crisis. The Premier League has come through the era when Pep Guardiola‚Äôs style, the precision in possession which took Manchester City to a treble in 2022-23, was everybody‚Äôs cup of tea. We‚Äôre now in a period where the Pep supremacy is being viewed with more disdain.
Some, such as ex-Manchester United defender Patrice Evra, think Guardiola drained the life out of football by turning players into ‚Äúrobots‚Äù. Whether driven by that attitude or not, the aesthetics of the Premier League are clearly changing. Long throws are back in business, passing numbers have fallen, long goal kicks and goals from headers are on the rise, and so are goals from set-pieces.
To Oli‚Äôs eye, the shift is making the spectacle attritional and ‚Äúa difficult watch‚Äù. ‚ÄúThose who accuse Guardiola of sucking the fun and creativity out of the game should be careful what they wish for,‚Äù he wrote. I have to be honest: I‚Äôm not in any way hating this season but a poll run by us found that 68 per cent of people are on Oli‚Äôs side. So where do you stand? Hit me at the usual email address.
Pass master: How Gundogan thrived under Guardiola and Klopp
Sticking with that theme, some food for thought: were it not for Guardiola, the Premier League would not have had the pleasure of Ilkay Gundogan in technicolour. Jordan Campbell met up with the German playmaker ‚Äî now at Galatasaray in Turkey ‚Äî for The Athletic‚Äôs My Game In My Words series. The piece is online this morning, and it‚Äôs superb.
Gundogan won‚Äôt go down as a Premier League great (that‚Äôs a very exclusive club) but he had it all: the passing, the movement, the assists and the goals. And what Jordan rightly notes is that no other player ever thrived so spectacularly under the coaching of both Guardiola and Jurgen Klopp.
Advertisement
In some ways, coping with those contrasting styles should be nigh-on impossible. In layman‚Äôs terms, they‚Äôre chalk and cheese, and players tend to have specific skill sets. But Gundogan possessed the brains and the talent to do it, and as I read him breaking down his own qualities, it occurred to me that, in an understated way, not many footballers have appealed to me more.
